<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 306, 220, 320]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 327, 304, 344]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Mechanics 2 (M2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 370, 418, 386]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 392, 460, 408]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 418, 390, 435]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 787, 464]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of this page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 325, 479]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 539, 910, 570]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 910, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 600, 724, 615]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 615, 593, 630]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 630, 606, 645]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 658, 606, 673]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 674, 756, 689]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 689, 440, 704]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
A uniform rectangular block has a square base \(ABCD\) with \(AB = BC = 0.4 \text{ m}\). The height of the block is \(h \text{ m}\). The block is placed with its base on a rough plane inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The block does not slide. It is given that the block is on the point of toppling when the diagonal \(AC\) lies along a line of greatest slope. Calculate \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
An object is projected with speed \(15 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{- 1}\) at an angle of \(35^{\circ}\) above the horizontal from a point on horizontal ground. Find the speed and direction of motion of the object at time 2 s after the instant of projection. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
A small ball \(B\) is connected to one end of a light elastic string of natural length \(0.4 \text{m}\) and modulus of elasticity \(12 \text{N}\). The other end of the string is attached to a fixed point \(A\). The ball is projected with speed \(1 \text{m s}^{-1}\) vertically downwards from a position \(0.4 \text{m}\) vertically below \(A\), and reaches its greatest speed at the point \(0.7 \text{m}\) below \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 152, 156, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 152, 430, 170]]<|/det|>
Show that the mass of \(B\) is \(0.9 \mathrm{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 395, 185, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 395, 425, 413]]<|/det|>
Calculate the greatest speed of \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 395, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
For the instant when \(P\) is at its greatest height above the ground, calculate this height and the corresponding value of \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 81, 702, 205]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 220, 920, 287]]<|/det|>
One end of a light inextensible string of length \(0.4 \mathrm{~m}\) is attached to the lowest point of a hemisphere of radius \(0.4 \mathrm{~m}\) fixed with its axis vertical. A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.3 \mathrm{~kg}\) is attached to the other end of the string. The string is straight and makes an angle of \(30^{\circ}\) with the horizontal. \(P\) moves on the smooth inner surface of the hemisphere in a horizontal circle (see diagram).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 299, 154, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 299, 562, 317]]<|/det|>
Calculate the smallest possible angular speed of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 300, 918, 317]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Given that the greatest possible tension in the string is \(5 \mathrm{~N}\), calculate the greatest possible speed of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 541, 92]]<|/det|>
When \(t = 8\) the force of magnitude \(P \mathsf{N}\) ceases to act.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 153, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 747, 122]]<|/det|>
Find the distance travelled by the object after \(t = 8\) before it comes to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[346, 85, 692, 312]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[496, 333, 546, 352]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 371, 920, 438]]<|/det|>
\(ABCD\) is a uniform square lamina with sides of length \(0.6 \mathrm{~m}\). A circular hole of radius \(r \mathrm{~m}\) is made in the lamina. The centre of the hole is \(0.3 \mathrm{~m}\) from \(AB\) and \(0.25 \mathrm{~m}\) from \(AD\). The lamina is freely suspended at \(A\) and hangs with the axis of symmetry making an angle of \(48^{\circ}\) with the horizontal (see Fig. 1).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 448, 154, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 448, 574, 467]]<|/det|>
Show that \(r = 0.214\), correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 448, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[484, 42, 512, 60]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 83, 692, 280]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 344, 918, 395]]<|/det|>
The lamina is held in equilibrium with \(AD\) horizontal by a force of magnitude \(15 \mathrm{~N}\) acting in the plane of the lamina applied at \(D\). The line of action of this force makes an angle of \(60^{\circ}\) with the vertical (see Fig. 2).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 408, 153, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 408, 734, 426]]<|/det|>
Find the weight of the original square lamina, before the hole was made.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 408, 918, 426]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 75, 569, 92]]<|/det|>
# Additional Page
